none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from W. A. Alexander, May 14, 1885
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from W. A. Alexander, May 14, 1885
Box 3 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 3 Folder 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers
Social life and customs--United States--19th century

en: A humorous and candid personal letter from W. A. Alexander, a clergyman, to his friend Louis L. McInnis, discussing his struggles with marriage and courtship in Canton (likely Canton, Mississippi). Alexander responds to McInnis's encouragement to marry by outlining the various obstacles he has encountered, including his indecisiveness, romantic failures, and his exacting standards for a potential wife regarding intellectual cultivation and family background. The letter reveals Alexander's wit, self-awareness, and the social expectations surrounding marriage in the American South during the 1880s.

body.value:
[Header]
Canton.. May 14th 1885

Dear Mc: I This morning rec'd your
letter, coming one day later than the
photo, & though I wrote to you yesterday, your
letter challenges my fresh considerations.
Especially your entreaties that I go forth
& marry, in order to be come like yourself
in happiness & glory, calls for my notice.
It affords me great comfort both on my
on account & on yours to have you say on the subject of marriage
like the Queen of Sheba of the wisdom of
Solomon, that the half had never been told
you, that the blessedness thereof far sur-
passes your most brilliant anticipations,
- on your account, I say because I wish
you all happiness, & on mine, because
the purpose I formed when a mere child
of marrying someday I have never
relinquished, but rather find it increasing
day by day. In fact I have come to the
full determination to tax my kind
congregation with the support of a woman

**Initial Thoughts and Analysis of the Handwritten Letter**

Okay, so I have this image of a handwritten letter, and my goal is to produce a transcription. Let's break this down systematically. First, I need to identify the crucial information. I see a date and location: "Canton May 14th 1885" at the top right. Next, there's the salutation. It reads "Dear Mc:". The 'c' looks like a small, slightly elevated character with two dots under it – a common shorthand for names like McCarthy. Let's examine the context: "...I this morning rec'd your letter...". The beginning of the body looks clear enough.

Now, let's start the line-by-line transcription. I am checking the text for potential errors. The handwriting is clear enough, but there are always minor quirks. "rec'd" is the contraction of "received". And the phrase "be come" is written as two words. There's a crossed-out word; I have to figure out what it is and how to transcribe it accurately. The letter seems to be an answer to an earlier letter and is focused on the subject of marriage, given the writer is replying to entreaties from the recipient.

I am re-checking the handwritten text, reading the text and making the corresponding transcription. I need to be careful with the formatting, spacing, and any unusual characters. I must re-check the formatting, especially interlinear insertions. Let's format the transcription correctly, preserving the meaning and the flow of the text. So the structure is:
1. Header: Date and location
2. Salutation: Dear Mc
3. Body of the Letter

So, here's my transcription in progress. First, the date and the salutation; this will include all interlinear and crossed-out text. The key to the process is preserving original spelling and punctuation, even any errors or strikethroughs by the author, and representing all insertions by the author.

After the initial transcription, the crucial part is to correctly handle the crossed-out text and insertions within the lines. There is a section of text on line 9 that is crossed out and replaced. I need to handle that carefully. The initial word is "marriage". There is also the phrase "on the subject of marriage" inserted, and there is a "caret" or mark that shows the location of the insertion. The prompt allows `<sup>` for superscript and `<sub>` for subscript and a few other tags, so let's use those properly.

After the process of working through the letter, here is the final, revised transcription:

```
Canton.. May 14<sup>th</sup> 1885

Dear M<sup>c</sup>: I This morning rec'd your
letter, coming one day later than the
photo, & though I wrote to you yesterday, your
letter challenges my fresh considerations.
Especially your entreaties that I go forth
& marry, in order to be come like yourself
in happiness & glory, calls for my notice.
It affords me great comfort both on my
on account & on yours to have you say <sup>on the subject of marriage</sup>
like the Queen of Sheba of the wisdom of
Solomon, that the half had never been told
you, that the blessedness thereof far sur-
passes your most brilliant anticipations,
- on your account, I say because I wish
you all happiness, & on mine, because
the purpose I formed when a mere child
of marrying someday I have never
relinquished, but rather find it increasing
day by day. In fact I have come to the
full determination to tax my kind
congregation with the support of a woman
```

on my account: provided I can make
the preliminary arrangements, these
mean, finding a girl, courting her, asking
the old man, & getting me a new pair of
boots. All these things have yet to be
attended to, [crossed out: (tho)] I am ready & spoiling,
I think I am a slow hand, & I seriously
contemplate referring these little arrange
-ments to a discreet committee of elderly
ladies in my church. It will afford
them entertainment & will hardly, so
pacific-minded they all are, lead to any
serious dissension. What is more, the
unanimity of their conclusions will
go far to fortify my mind with stoic
courage for the leap.- Some such method
must be resorted to, for not only am I begin-
-ning to be counted a hard case, but I am
even ^ getting desperate myself. This desperation
grows day by day as my gray hairs show
more & more plainly on my temples -
I am really anxious to get married
sometime before I die, which anxiety is

The instructions say to interpret handwritten text and to transcribe all text. * I'm also noting the insertion in line 19. The word "even" appears to be written above "getting", so I'll need to figure out how to represent that (using `even`). I'm also including the caret, `^`. * I am reading carefully the words to make sure they are written accurately. is made the more intense by the knowledge that
in heaven they neither marry nor are
given in marriage, so that my only
chance is to marry in this world while yet
the "lamp of life holds out to burn". - -

The great trouble with me is every time
I get in love, either I change my mind
or the girl changes hers.. I thought I was
going to make it sure, a few years ago
but I wasnt ready & she couldnt
wait, & so was guilty of the folly & bad
taste of going & taking another fellow.
After getting over the chagrin of being
invited to take a back seat, I came to
be really glad that I was still at liberty
& have often inwardly thanked the other fellow for
taking her off my hands.. Since then
my experience has been that of the old
maid (pardon me, I should have said,
belated sister) who said that those she
would have, she couldnt get, & those
she could get, even the devil wouldnt
have, only I dont go the full lengths of the

last clause. The Bingham blood
is beginning to assert itself in me with the
effect, that like our amorous college friend,
I fall in love with nearly every girl I see,
love them all hard, & the last, the hardest.
If I could be shut up to the necessity, or I might
better say, could be favored with the privilege of being
thrown constantly with one to the exclusion
of all other charmers, I could doubtless
persuade myself that my fate was
sealed & I at the end of all my troubles -
At which end, I do not know. You say the
last end, a few soured individuals
who are never so happy as when they are
perfectly miserable, would say at the beginning.
But taking a Pisgah top view of
the situation, I will declare honestly
to you how the land lies before me, & you
may tell every body that is disposed
to censure my dilatoriness, Though the
girls are hereabouts as thick as dogfennel
& lovely & all that, yet they nearly all have

mingling with their many virtues, some
fatal blemish. I fear I think too much
of this, since she who forsakes father & mother
& kindred for me, will get a whole bundle
of defects & blemishes. I fear I am asking
too much boot. But to Particularize: But
few of the girls of this generations are ambitious to cultivate their
minds, or [crossed out: seek to gain] to add to their Knowledge. The majority
are delighted with the attainments & the society
of mere dudes. There are as many Doodles
among the young women of the land as
there are dudes among the young men.
In this respect, I wish to avoid an unequal
match, [crossed out: in this respect]. My home was one of
cultivation. My brothers & sisters have toiled
& do yet toil, to gain that refinement which
our best schools & best books & best society gives.
I do not care to take into [crossed out: (one of)] the circle, one
who will rank inferior, in the qualities of
her mind. Then the girls "in this district" all
chew gum & use slang" & are otherwise, awful.
Another thing, there is a sense in which
no man marries a wife without marrying the

whole family. i.e. He takes them into his home
& into the circle of his relations. This makes
it necessary that one look well to the home &
family that he espouses. To a christian
man, this implies that it should be one
of the covenanted families of God, where
in all its members & appointments, that
course is pursued which invites the favor
of heaven & the smiles of an approving
providence - It is nt every family that
I would marry into. It wont hurt to be
a little particular. What bothers me is this,
that every time I begin seriously to think
of any particular lady, & run over in my
mind the best form of "speech" to make
to her to make an impression, I hear
ere my hesitancy has culminated in a
proposal. that she is going to marry
some one else. I had laid my plans
last fall for one, I thought I had her sure,
but lo. I got a beautiful letter, just-then from
a gentleman up the R.R. I never heard
of before asking me to solemnize the rites

**Detailed Transcription Thought Process**

But I'll make notes for later to be sure I'm following standards or expectations. It looks like it is `i,e,`, and I will transcribe as that, to be precise. Also, "them into" looks like two separate words.

*   **Line 2**: I see "and" represented with something that looks like a plus sign. I'll need to figure out how to represent that. It looks like a plus sign often used as "and." I'll use "+" for now, but I will check other instances to see if it is used elsewhere. It is definitely a "+". Checking my sources for transcription norms. Most of the time, I'd expand this to the ampersand `&` because it is the standard and the plus sign will be confusing. But the instructions are for "spelling...punctuation". This writer uses `+`. I'll use `+`. Correction, I'll use `&`.

    I will double-check "relations". The "s" is clear.

*   **Line 3**: "necessary" is spelled correctly. "Home +". Okay, another "+."

of matrimony between him & this lady.
I did it & try to be satisfied. I consoled
myself with the knowledge that there was
another here in town I liked as well, &
maybe the Providential taking away of
one was an indication that the other
was appointed of heaven for my solace –
The thought elated me & I was more than
satisfied with the prospect. But as things
were going, I saw that it was impossible
for us to marry before fall & hence there
was no need of hurry & I could take all
winter & early spring to think about it.
I even went so far about Christmas as to write out
a few notes for a speech (They are in
my drawer yet, I saw them only the other
day) but concluded I had better go on
& make an impression first. – When
lo, the fact has cropped out this spring
that she is so far mortgaged to a distant
fellow that to attempt changing her mind
would either lead to disappointment in
my case, or heart the other fellow's feelings,

**Initial Analysis and Transcription of Handwritten Text** Alright, let's dive into this transcription. First things first, the image presents a page of handwritten text—looks like a letter or journal entry. The handwriting is cursive, a bit hasty but generally legible. There's a slight watermark or texture on the paper, and a clip mark at the top left. The language is English, of course. Now, line-by-line: * **Line 1:** The text concerns "of matrimony between him & this lady". Looks like we're picking up mid-thought from a previous page about a bond or state. That "&" there... that's a quick scribble, a shorthand for "and," and I'll use that unless the handwriting makes it look like something else. * **Line 2:** "I did it & try to be satisfied. I consoled." Hmm, the "try" is key. Makes sense. Or is it "beg"? No, it's definitely "try" looking at the strokes. * **Line 3-7:** Self-reflection follows. "myself with the knowledge that there was / another here in town I liked as well, & / maybe the providential taking away of / one was an indication that the other / was appointed of heaven for my solace –" Sounds like someone found an alternative. "Appointed of" - yes. It looks like it. * **Line 8-13:** The tone shifts: "The thought elated me & I was more than / satisfied with the prospect. But as things / were going, I saw that it was impossible / for us to marry before fall & hence there / was no need of hurry & I could take all / winter & early spring to think about it." A bit of careful consideration. * **Line 14:** Now, here's a bit of editing. There's a word crossed out: "~~When~~ I even went so far ^about Christmas^ as to write out". The insertion "about Christmas" is clear. I will write "I even went so far about Christmas as". * **Line 15-18:** "a few notes for a speech (They are in / my drawer yet, I saw them only the other / day) but concluded I had better go on / & make an impression first. – When." He's gathering his thoughts. * **Line 19-23:** Oh-oh, the twist. "lo, the fact has cropped out this spring / that she is so far mortgaged to a distant / fellow that to attempt changing her mind / would either lead to disappointment in / my case, or heart the other fellow's feelings." The last word... is it "heart" or "hurt"? The handwriting is a bit unclear, but it looks like "h-e-a-r-t". So, I will transcribe that. Now, a quick bit of review. The ampersand is clear, it's "&" or maybe "+". I will stick to "&". The crossed-out word in line 14: let's omit it as it is heavily scribbled. "Heart" or "hurt" in line 23. It definitely looks like "heart" to me. **Refined Transcription and Formatting** Okay, taking a step back: * **Line 1:** "of matrimony between him & this lady." * **Line 2:** "I did it & try to be satisfied." The "try" is clear. * **Line 4:** "another here in town I liked as well, &" * **Line 7:** "appointed of heaven" * **Line 14:** "I even went so far about Christmas as to write out" - I'll represent the insertion as `about Christmas`. * **Line 23:** "my case, or heart the other fellow's feelings,". And yes, "feelings". I can't use HTML elements to show crossed out text. So let's skip the crossed-out text to be consistent with the reading. Now to format this into a valid transcription. Looks like the page number is at the top left. Let's include it. **Final Formatting and Transcription** Alright, here's the final version: **4** **of matrimony between him & this lady.**

which I would hate to do, as I am
told he is a clever, harmless fellow.
So you see that "my troubles are
many, my pleasures are few." -
& I am just jogging along, "waiting
only waiting till the shadows are
a little longer grown" - with age
will come greater wisdom, & I
may yet reform my ways -
A word of encouragement
from you, or advice will go far
towards straightening out

[Signature]
Yours truly
W. A. Alexander

[Header]

Canton May 14th 1885

[Body]

Dear Mc: I this morning rec'd your letter, coming one day later than the
photo, & though I wrote to you yesterday, your letter challenges my fresh consider-
ation. Especially your entreaties that I go forth & marry in order to be come
like yourself in happiness & glory calls for my notice. It affords me great
comfort both on my on /sic/ account & on yours to have you say on the subject
of marriage like the queen of Sheba of the Wisdom of Solomon, that the half
had never been told you, that the blessedness thereof far surpasses your most
brilliant anticiaptions. On your account, I say because I wish you all happi-
ness. & on mine because the purpose I formed when a mere child of marrying
some day I x have never relinquished, but rather find it increasing day by day.
In fact I have come to the full determination to tax my kind congregation with
the support of a woman on my account provided I can make the preliminary ar-
rangements. These mean finding a girl, courting her, asking the old man, &
getting me a new pair of boots. All these things have yet to be attended to.
(The)- I am ready & spoiling. I think I am a slow haxd hand, & I seriously
contemplate referring these little arrangements to a discreet committee of
elderly ladies in my church. It will afford them entertainment. & will hardly,
so pacific-minded they all are, lead to any serious dissention. What is more,
the unanimity of their conclusions will go for to fortify my mind with store
courage for the leap. Some such method must be resorted to, for not only am
I beginning to be counted a hard case, but I am even getting desperate myself.
This desperation grows day by day as my gray hairs show more & more plainly on

my temples. I am really anxious to get married sometime before I die, which
anxiety is made/the moreintense by the knowledge that in heaven they neither marry
nor are given in marriage. So that my only chance is to ------- marry/in this world while
yet the Xxxmpx "lamp of life haolds out to burn" --

The great trouble with me is every time I get in love, either I change my
mind or the girl changes hers. I thought I was going to make it sure, a few
years ago but I wasn't ready & she coundn't wait, & so was guilty of the folly
& bad taste of going & taking another fellow. After getting over the chagrin
of being invited to take a back seat, I came to be really glad that I was still
at liberty & have often/inwardly thanked the other fellow for taking her off my hands.
Since then my experience has been that of the old maid (pardon me, I should have
said belated sister) who said that those she would have, she couldn't get, &
those she could get, even the devil wouldn't have, only I don't go the full
length of the last senten clause. The Bingham blood is beginning to assert it-
self in me with the effect, that like our amorous college friend, I fall in love
with nearly every girl I see, love them all hard, & the last, the hardest. If
I could be shut up to the necessity or/I might better say could be favored with the privilege of
being thrown constantly with one to the exclusion of all other charmers, I could
doubtless persuade myself that my fate was sealed & I at the end of all my troubles.
At which end, I do not know. You say the last end, a few soured individuals
who are never so happy as when they are perfectly miserable, would say at the
beginning.

But taking a top view of the situation, I wll declare honestly
to you how the land lies before me, & you may tell mx everybody that is disposed

to censure my dilatoriness. Though the girls are hereabouts as thick as dog
& lovely & all that, yet they nearly all have mingling with their many
virtues, some fatal blemish. I fear I think too much of this since she who for-
sakes father & mother & kindred for me, will get a whole bundle of defects &
blemishes. I fear I am asking too much boot. But to particularize: But few
of the girls/of this generation are ambitious to cultivate their minds or seek-to-gainto add to their knowledge.
The majority are delighted with the attainments & the society of mere dudes.
There are as many Doodles among the young women of the land as there are dudes
among the young men. In this respect, I wish to avoid an unequal match. In-this
respect- My home was one of cultivation. My brothers & sisters have toiled
& do yet toil, to gain that refinement which our best schools & best books &
best society gives. I do not care to take into (our-f)- the circle, one who will
rank inferior, in the qualities of her mind. Then the girls "in this district"
all chew gum & use slang" & are otherwise, awful. Another thing, there is a sense
in which no man arries a wife without marrying the whole family, i.e. He takes
them into his home & into the circle of his relations. This makes it necessary
that one look well to the home & family that he espouses. To a Christian man,
this implies that it should be one of the covenanted families of God, where
in all its members & appointments, that course is pursued which invites the favor
of heaven & the smiles of an approving providence. It is not every family that
I would marry into. I won't hurt to be a little particular. What bothers me
is this, that everytime I begin seriously to think of any particular lady, & run
over in my mind the best form of "speech" to make to her to make an impression,
I hear ere my hxxxx hesitancy has culuminted in a proposal that she is going to
to marry someone else . I had laid my plans last fall for one, I thought I had

& do yet toil, to gain that refinement which our best schools & best books &
best society gives. I do not care to take into (our-f)- the circle, one who will
rank inferior, in the qualities of her mind. Then the girls "in this district"
all chew gum & use slang" & are otherwise, awful. Another thing, there is a sense
in which no man arries a wife without marrying the whole family, i.e. He takes
them into his home & into the circle of his relations. This makes it necessary

this implies that it should be one of the covenanted families of God, where
in all its members & appointments, that course is pursued which invites the favor
of heaven & the smiles of an approving providence. It is not every family that
I would marry into. I won't hurt to be a little particular. What bothers me
is this, that everytime I begin seriously to think of any particular lady, & run
over in my mind the best form of "speech" to make to her to make an impression,
I hear ere my hxxxx hesitancy has culuminted in a proposal that she is going to
to marry someone else . I had laid my plans last fall for one, I thought I had

her sure, but lo, I got a beautiful letter/ just then from a gentleman up the R. R. I
never heard of before asking me to solemnize the rites of matrimony between him
& this lady. I did it & x try to be satisfied. I consoled myself with the
knowledge that there was another here in town I liked as well, & xxx maybe the
providential taking away of the other was appointed of heaven for my solace.
The thought elated me & I was more than satisfied with the prospect. But as
things were going I saw that it was impossible for us to marry before fall &
hence there was no need of hurry & I could take all winter & early spring to
think about it. When I even went so far/ about Christmas to write out a few notes for a speech
( They are in my drawer yet, I saw them only the other day) but concluded I had
better go on & make an impression first. When lo, the fact has cropped out
this spring that she is so for mortgaged to a distant fellow that to attempt
changing her mind would either lead to disappointment in my case, or hxxxx
hurt the other fellow's feelings, which I would hate to do, as I am told he
is a clever, harmless fellow.

So you see that "my troubles are many, my pleasures are few." & I am just
jogging along, "waiting only waiting till the shadows are a little longer grown"-
With age will come greater wisdom & I may yet reform my ways. A word of encourageme
from you, or advice will go far towards straightening out

Yours truly,

W. A. Alexander
